titleStmt.title: Effect of composing element on microstructure and mechanical properties in MoeNbeHfeZreTi multi-principle component alloys

analytic.title: Effect of composing element on microstructure and mechanical properties in MoeNbeHfeZreTi multi-principle component alloys

biblStruct.note: Received 27 April 2015 Received in revised form 10 October 2015 Accepted 17 October 2015

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: High-entropy alloys Mechanical properties Microstructure Phase stability Prediction

div.p: A series of non-equiatomic MoeNbeHfeZreTi alloys are synthesized to investigate the effects of the concentration variation of each composing elements on the microstructure and mechanical properties. It is found that all studied alloys form single body-centered-cubic (BCC) phase only with the variation of the lattice parameter, which indicates that the concentration variation of each composing elements has no effect on the phase constitutes. All studied alloys exhibit typically dendritic and interdendritic structure while the concentration variation of each composing elements has different effects on the microsegregation. The concentration variation of Zr leads to the most serious microsegregation. Elements with a higher melting point such as Mo and Nb solidify preferentially and thus are enriched in the dendrites. Both the increase and decrease of the concentration of each composing element reduce the hardness and strength of non-equiatomic MoeNbeHfeZreTi alloys compared with the equiatomic MoNbHfZrTi alloy.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: High-entropy alloys or multi-principle component alloys were defined by Yeh et al. as equiatomic or near-equiatomic alloys containing at least five principal elements with the concentration between 5 at% and 35 at% [1e3]. Since proposed, high-entropy alloys have attracted extensive research attention due to the simple phase constitutes and excellent properties, which are mainly composed of face-centered-cubic (FCC) and/or body-centered-cubic (BCC) solid solutions [4e10]. Depending on their compositions and microstructure, high-entropy alloys usually possess excellent properties such as high hardness and strength, good thermal stability, and good corrosion resistance [11e14]. So far, there are two kinds of high-entropy alloy systems. One alloy system is mainly based on such elements as Fe, Cr, Ni, Mn, Co, Al and Cu, such as the typical alloy CoCrFeMnNi [15e17]. For this alloy system, extensive investigations on microstructure, phase stability and mechanical properties have been carried out [18e21]. The other alloy system is nearly exclusively based on refractory elements such as W, Nb, Zr, Mo, Ta and Hf, which are named as refractory high-entropy alloys [8,22e25]. Refractory high-entropy alloys may become potential candidates aimed at overcoming the limitation on applicable temperature of superalloys. For example, NbMoTaW and VNbMo-TaW alloys with a single bcc solid solution phase have high yield strength up to 405 MPa and 477 MPa at 1873 K and exhibit the stronger resistance to high-temperature softening possibly due to the slow diffusion effect of multiprinciple elements compared with the Ni-based superalloys of Inconel 718 and Haynes 230 [8,22]. NbCrMo 0.5 Ta 0.5 TiZr alloy has a better combination of mechanical properties and oxidation resistance than commercial Nb-based alloys and earlier reported developmental NbeSieAleTi and NbeSieMo alloys [23,24]. AlMo 0.5 NbTa 0.5 TiZr alloy with two BCC phases has a lower density of 7.4 g/cm 3 and its yield strength is 2000 MPa at 298 K and 745 MPa at 1273 K [25]. Therefore, refractory high-entropy alloys offer a new strategy for the development of high strength alloys for elevated-temperature application.

In all reported refractory high-entropy alloys, TaNbHfZrTi alloy has good plasticity at room temperature while the density is high [26]. By replacing Ta in TaNbHfZrTi alloy with Mo, the density and cost are decreased. And the strength is also significantly improved after replacing Ta with Mo [27]. Many other reported high-entropy alloys have equiatomic or near equiatomic compositions while varying concentrations of individual elements can significantly affect both microstructure and properties of the alloys [28]. For example, the yield strength increases from 230 MPa (x ¼ 0) to 1272 MPa (x ¼ 1.0) with the increase of Ti concentration in CoCr-CuFeNiTi x alloys [29]. In AlCoCrFeMo0.5Ni x alloys, the constituent phases change from B2 þ s phases at x ¼ 0 to B2 þ FCC þ s phases at x ¼ 2.0 as Ni concentration increases [30]. In Al x CoCrCuFeNi alloys, both the volume fraction of BCC phase and the hardness value increase, and the wear coefficient decreases with increasing aluminum concentration [13]. Thus, an integrated study on the effects of composing element on the microstructure and properties is useful for understanding the phase formation and essential for exploring compositions with promising properties.

In this paper, a series of non-equiatomic MoeNbeHfeZreTi alloys were prepared by arc melting. The concentration of each composing element has two levels (0.5 and 1.5 in molar ratio). The phase constitutes, microstructure, microhardness and mechanical properties were investigated. Two main objectives are to be pursued: (1) to gain new understanding on the effect of composing element on phase and microstructure in the MoeNbeHfeZreTi alloys; (2) to elaborate the effect of composing element on the mechanical properties for optimizing this alloy.

div.head: Experimental procedures
div.p: Alloy ingots of MoeNbeHfeZreTi, that are Nb 0.5 MoTiZrHf, Nb 1.5 MoTiZrHf, NbMoTi 0.5 ZrHf, NbMoTi 1.5 ZrHf, NbMoTiZr 0.5 Hf, NbMoTiZr 1.5 Hf, NbMoTiZrHf 0.5 , NbMoTiZrHf 1.5 , NbMo 0.5 TiZrHf 0.5 and NbMo 1.5 TiZrHf denoted as Nb0.5, Nb1.5, Ti0.5, Ti1.5, Zr0.5, Zr1.5, Hf0.5, Hf1.5, Mo0.5Hf0.5 and Mo1.5, respectively, were prepared by arc melting in high-purity argon atmosphere inside a water-cooled copper crucible. All elements have the purity higher than 99.6 weight percent. The nominal chemical compositions of all alloys are listed in Table 1. All ingots were re-melted for five times to ensure the chemical homogeneity. The button ingots are about 35 mm of diameter and 15 mm of height. The lowermost part of the button ingots, which is in direct contact with the water-cooled crucible, has the highest cooling rate, so the microstructure is usually fine equiaxed grains. The uppermost part solidifies lastly, in which there may be some solidification defects such as shrinkages. The microstructure for the middle part is relatively more uniform. Thus all samples tested and analyzed were cut from the middle part of the ingots. The crystal structure was investigated using X-Ray diffraction (XRD) with the 2q scan ranging from 20 to 100 deg at a speed of 5 deg/min. The radiation condition was 45 KV and 40 mA with a copper target. The microstructure was investigated by the scanning electron microscope (SEM) and the chemical compositions were analyzed by SEM energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). Vickers microhardness, HV, was measured on polished crosssection surfaces under a 1 Kg load applied for 20 s. Each alloy was measured eleven times and the spacing is about 0.5 mm. The maximum and minimum values are removed and the average value of other nine values is the hardness of each alloy. The room temperature compressive properties were evaluated using an Instron 5569 testing machine. The test specimens are in the shape of a cylinder (44 mm Â 6 mm). The strain rate is 1 Â 10 À3 s À1 . Each alloy was tested for four times under the same testing conditions.

div.head: Phase constitute
div.p: XRD patterns of non-equiatomic MoeNbeHfeZreTi alloys are shown in Fig. 1. All alloys form single BCC phase only with the variation of the lattice parameters, which indicates that the concentration variation of composing element in the investigated concentration range has no effect on the phase constitutes. And there are no any ordered diffraction peaks which indicate that the single BCC phase is disordered. The indexes of the crystal planes (h, k, l) corresponding to the XRD peaks are marked in Fig. 1. The lattice parameters (a) can be calculated as the following formulation:
div.formula: a ¼ d hkl ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi ffi h 2 þ k 2 þ l 2 p (1
div.p: The lattice parameters of ten non-equiatomic alloys are listed in Table 2. If the lattice parameter of the equiatomic NbMoTiZrHf alloy is considered as the base and defined as a 0 (338.1 pm), the lattice parameter difference can be expressed as Da ¼ a i À a 0 , in which a i is the lattice parameter of non-equiatomic alloys, to investigate the effect of the concentration variation of each composing element on the lattice parameter. The lattice parameter difference of the single BCC phase as a function of element concentration is depicted in Fig. 2. As shown, the lattice parameter difference is the maximum when the molar ratio of Zr element is 0.5. The increase or decrease of Mo concentration induces the larger lattice parameter difference except Zr0.5 alloy.

div.head: Microstructure
div.p: Microstructure of MoeNbeHfeZreTi alloys is displayed in Fig. 3 and Fig. 4. Fig. 3 exhibits the SEM-BSE images of MoeNbeHfeZreTi alloys before etching. Similar to the equiatomic as-cast NbMoTiZrHf alloy, in which there is no obvious chemical microsegregation, the elemental distribution is still relatively homogeneous for Nb0.5, To observe the microstructure, all alloys were etched using the hydrofluoric acid, nitric acid and distilled water (HF:HNO 3 :H 2 O ¼ 1:1:8). Fig. 4 shows the microstructure after etching. All alloys exhibit the typically dendritic and interdendritic structure. The needle precipitates become more obvious in Nb1.5 alloy. Fig. 5 shows the bright field TEM images and the selected area electron diffraction in Nb1.5 alloy. There are amounts of dislocations near the sub-boundaries and precipitates. As shown in Fig. 5 (a), some wide parallel dislocations distribute in the matrix. The selected area electron diffraction of the matrix confirms that the matrix is a disordered BCC phase. In the matrix, there are also some granular and plate precipitates surrounded and winded by amounts of dislocations as shown in Fig. 5 (b) ~(d). The selected area electron diffractions of the matrix show that these precipitates are also the disordered BCC phase. The EDS analysis shows that these granular precipitates are enriched Mo and depleted with Nb and Hf compared with that of the matrix. TheseTEM results further confirm that Nb1.5 alloy is composed of one disordered BCC phase.

div.head: Mechanical properties
div.p: Microhardness values of MoeNbeHfeZreTi alloys are given in Fig. 6. Both the increase and the decrease of the concentration of each composing element result in the decrease of the microhardness compared with the hardness of 494 HV for the equiatomic MoNbHfZrTi alloy. The Hf0.5 alloy has the highest hardness and Mo0.5Hf0.5 alloy has the lowest hardness in the non-equiatomic MoeNbeHfeZreTi alloys.

Mechanical properties of MoeNbeHfeZreTi alloys were also studied using compressive testing. The representative compressive strain-stress curves are shown in Fig. 7. The mechanical properties such as yield strength, s 0.2 , peak strength, s p , and fracture strain ε are summarized in Table 2. As reported, the equitatomic MoN-bHfZrTi alloy has the yield strength, peak strength and fracture strain of 1719 MPa, 1803 MPa and 10.12% at room temperature, respectively [29]. The concentration variation of each composing element results in the decrease of the compressive yield strength, that is very similar to the result of the hardness, while the plasticity of the non-equiatomic MoeNbeHfeZreTi alloys is improved. In all non-equiatomic alloys, Hf0.5 alloy has the highest yield strength and Mo0.5Hf0.5 alloy has the lowest yield strength, which is similar to the result of the hardness.

div.head: Effect of composing elements on phase formation
div.p: The present work shows the increase or decrease of the concentration of each composing elements does not change the phase constitute within the investigated concentration range. It can be inferred that this alloy system may remain the single BCC phase in which each element has the concentration between 11.11 at% and 27.27 at%. The simple solid solution phases are expected in highentropy alloys. There are many attempts trying to reveal the rules of the solid solution phase formation from the thermodynamic view. The phase formation of the high-entropy alloys was initially proposed to be dominated by the high mixing entropy [2]:

Table 2 Lattice parameter (a, pm), DS mix (J K À1 mol À1 ),DH mix (kJ mol À1 ), U, d (%), VEC, hardness (HV), the yield strength (s 0.2 , MPa), the peak strength (s p , MPa), and the fracture strain (ε, %) of MoeNbeHfeZreTi alloys. DS mix ¼ ÀR
div.formula: X n i¼1 C i ln C i (2
div.p: where R is the gas constant and C i is the atomic fraction of element i. The high mixing entropy can significantly lower the free energy and inhibit the formation of intermetallic or other complicated phases especially at high temperature. However, further research shows that high mixing entropy is not a useful priori predictor and enthalpy and non-configurational entropy have also great influence on phase constitutes [31]. In accord to Hume-Rothery rules for binary substitutional solid solutions, Zhang et al. suggested a criterion for achieving solid solution phases using two parameters of mixing enthalpy and atomic radius difference, DH mix and d, as expressed below [32]:
div.formula: d ¼ ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi X n i¼1 C i ð1 À r i =rÞ 2 v u u t(3)
DH mix ¼ 4 X n i¼1;isj DH mix ij C i C j (4
div.p: Where r i is the atomic radius of element i and DH mix ij is the mixing enthalpy between element i and element j. Analyzing the available data of the reported high entropy alloys, À15 < DH mix < 5 kJ/mol and 5% < d < 6.6% are the criteria for forming solid solution phases in high-entropy alloys [32]. To further consider the combined effects of mixing entropy and mixing enthalpy, the parameter of U was proposed [33]:
div.formula: U ¼ T mix DS mix jDH mix j(5)
div.p: where T mix is the average melting temperature which can be calculated as:
div.formula: T mix ¼ X n i¼1 ðT m Þ i(6)
div.p: where (T m ) i is the melting temperature of element i. It is calculated that U < 1.1 and d < 6.6% are the criteria for forming single solid solution phase [33]. The values of DS mix , DH mix , d, and U for MoeNbeHfeZreTi alloys are listed in Table 2. The values of all studied alloys in this paper fall into the zone where single solid solution phases will form. Therefore, the single solid solution phase should have high crystal structure stability thermodynamically for all studied alloys. The concentration increase or decrease of each composing element only leads to the variation of the lattice parameter. The concentration variation of Zr and Mo has the more significant effect on the lattice parameter difference, which may be attributed to the larger atomic size difference between Mo or Zr and other elements.

div.head: Effect of composing elements on microstructure and compositions
div.p: The concentration variation of each composing element has no obvious effect on the microstructure while exhibits different effect on the microsegregation. All studied alloys are typically dendritic and interdendritic structure. The degree of the microsegregation can be expressed using the segregation ratio of S R as:
div.formula: S R ¼ ðC B Þ i ðC A Þ i(7)
div.p: where (C A ) i is the atomic fraction of element i in the zone A and (C B ) i is the atomic fraction of element i in the zone B. The calculated results are shown in Table 3. It can be concluded that the elements with higher melting points (Mo and Nb) solidified firstly in one region and the elements with lower melting points (Zr and Hf) were rejected into the other region. Besides the effect of melting points on the microsegregation, it can be found that the degree of segregation is related with the lattice parameter difference. The alloys with the larger lattice parameter difference have the more serious segregation compared with the equiatomic MoNbHfZrTi alloy. For example, the microsegregation of Zr0.5 alloy with the largest lattice parameter difference is the most serious. This is rational since all elements are distributed homogeneously in the equiatomic MoNbHfZrTi alloy in which the five elements occupy the BCC lattice randomly while the segregation decreases the configurational randomness in the non-equiatomic MoeNbeHfeZreTi alloys. The lattice parameter difference in MoeNbeHfeZreTi alloys is mainly attributed to two aspects compared with the equiatomic MoNbHfZrTi alloy: (1) the concentration variation of element with larger atomic radius difference with other elements has more significant effect on the lattice parameter difference; (2) the more serious segregation degree may lead to a larger lattice parameter.

div.head: Effect of composing elements on mechanical properties
div.p: The hardness and strength of non-equiatomic MoeNbeHfeZreTi alloys are reduced compared with the equiatomic MoNbHfZrTi alloy. For the alloys with the single BCC solid solution phase, the dominant strengthening mechanism is solid solution strengthening which originates from the distortion of the crystalline lattice induced by solute atoms which interact with dislocations and prevent the motion of the dislocations necessary for the plastic deformation. While all component atoms can be known as the solute atoms or solvent atoms which are substituted mutually in the BCC phase for the high-entropy alloys. It is deduced that the distortion of the crystalline lattice is the most serious in the equiatomic alloy. The research shows that the hardness and strength have the close relationship with the average valence concentration (VEC) and the atomic size difference (d) for single phase high-entropy alloys [34]. The VEC is defined as:
div.formula: VEC ¼ X n i¼1 C i ðVECÞ i(8)
div.p: where (VEC) i is the valence electron concentration of element i. It was reported that the hardness increases monotonously with the atomic size difference [34]. The values of d and HV are listed in Table 2 and Fig. 6. It can be observed that the hardness and strength have no obvious relationship with the atomic size difference and average valence concentration. This is rational since the chemical segregation may have effect on actual atomic size difference and average valence concentration. For example, the atomic size difference in the dark regions and white regions of Zr0.5 alloy is 4.62% and 5.82%, respectively. The actual atomic size difference of Zr0.5 alloy must be below the calculated value of 5.86% when the fraction of the dark regions is close to zero or one. Therefore, the segregation should be taken into account when investigating the relationship between hardness, strength and d, VEC.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In the current work, microstructure and mechanical properties of non-equiatomic MoeNbeHfeZreTi alloys with each element at 0.5 and 1.5 in molar ratio were studied and compared with that of the equiatomic MoNbHfZrTi alloy. The concentration variation of each composing element does not change the phase constitute. The alloy may remain the single body-centered cubic (BCC) solid solution phase in which each composing element has the concentration between 11.11 at% and 27.27 at%. The parameters of mixing entropy (DS mix ), atomic radius difference (d), mixing enthalpy (DH mix ) and U (the combined effects of mixing entropy and mixing enthalpy) can be used for predicting the phase formation of MoeNbeHfeZreTi alloys. The concentration variation of composing elements has different effects on the microsegregation in which Zr element has the most significant effect on the microsegregation. The concentration increase or decrease of each composing elements decreases the hardness and strength while improves the plasticity due to the weakened solution strengthening.

figure.figDesc: Fig. 1. figure.figDesc: Fig. 2. figure.figDesc: Fig. 3. figure.figDesc: Fig. 4. SEM images of MoeNbeHfeZreTi alloys before etching: (a) Nb 0.5 MoTiZrHf (Nb0.5), (b) Nb 1.5 MoTiZrHf (Nb1.5), (c) NbMoTi 0.5 ZrHf (Ti0.5), (d) NbMoTi 1.5 ZrHf (Ti1.5), (e) NbMoTiZr 0.5 Hf (Zr0.5), (f) NbMoTiZr 1.5 Hf (Zr1.5), (g) NbMoTiZrHf 0.5 (Hf0.5), (h) NbMoTiZrHf 1.5 (Hf1.5), (i) NbMo 0.5 TiZrHf 0.5 (Mo0.5Hf0.5), (j) NbMo 1.5 TiZrHf alloys (Hf1.5).

figure.figDesc: Fig. 6.
